results.title: Food for a small planet
results.brief_description: Pictures the human battle against hunger from the beginning of time. Includes scenes of starvation which are contrasted with views of affluence and waste. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Food and people
results.brief_description: Draws a contrast between people who have plenty to eat and those who have next to nothing. Followers of Thomas Malthus are convinced that a world of plenty will never be possible; others believe the world’s population should be limited; and another group advocates the increase of food production and distribution. The latter concept also stresses conservation of resources and improved agricultural methods. Emphasises that with free world trade, peoples of all nations will benefit. Suggests that a world of plenty provides greater chances for individual security and world peace.

results.title: Food and growth
results.brief_description: Explains the functions of the mouth, stomach and intestine in the digestion of food. Shows how food is carried by the circulatory system to the cells, allowing cell division and growth. Suitable for upper primary and lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Food additives
results.creator_credit: Deborah Manners, Open Tafe, Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education and Shane Mulcahy
results.brief_description: A discussion with Dr. K. Farrer, author of “Fancy eating that” who describes the history of food additives and examines what is added and why. He also addresses the safety aspects of additives and regulations to control their use. Hosted by Peter Couchman.

results.title: Food (for) thought
results.creator_credit: Dennis Tupicoff, Victorian College of the Arts and Daniel Crooks
results.brief_description: Food. Religion. Television. Using a multiplicity of styles, this technically accomplished animation seeks to present a critique of religion and consumer culture. It makes an impressive idiosyncratic statement, with stylistic references to Jan Svankmajer and the Brothers Quay.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dennis Tupicoff, Victorian College of the Arts and Daniel Crooks

results.title: Food
results.creator_credit: Pat Hunder, Garry Dunstan and It's About Time
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Not suitable for adults”.
A light hearted look at food by a group of “hungry” teenagers. Diets, fads, junk food addiction are discussed in a series of comic sketches and original songs. Information about nutrition and healthy lifestyle eating in a palatable format for adolescents.

results.title: Food
results.brief_description: An animated film, without commentary, produced by a guest filmmaker from India, Gopal K. Gokhale, during a period of workstudy at the National Film Board. The film is intended to demonstrate to farm audiences in developing countries how improved farming practices and technology increase crop yield and income. Film without words.

results.title: Fonteyn and Nureyev: The perfect partnership
results.creator_credit: Peter Batty and Peter Batty Productions
results.brief_description: Narrated by Robert Powell, this is the remarkable story of the unique dancing collaboration of Margot Fonteyn and Rudolph Nureyev that brought joy to millions around the world. Thought by many to be the most sensational partnership ever, it is certainly one against which all others will be judged. Theirs was a collaboration of two very contrasting personalities. Fonteyn, an experienced ballerina, idolized already for her own achievements and for whom stardom seemed an effortless progression. Nureyev, half her age and relatively unknown, had to thrust his way into a dancing career against the advice of family and friends. This wonderful voyage through their careers together is filled with the opinions and reminisces of the friends and contemporaries and some rare and intimate footage of the perfect partners. It includes performances from the ballets; Romeo and Juliet, Le Corsaire, Giselle, Swan Lake, Marguerite and Armand, Les Sylphides, Birthday Offering, Hamlet Prelude and Lucifer.

results.title: Fontane Effi Briest = Effi Briest
results.creator_credit: Tango Film, Filverlag der Authoren and Rainer Werner Fassbinder
results.brief_description: Possibly Fassbinder’s most exquisite film, this is the story of a seventeen year old girl stifled in a loveless marriage, too naive to understand that her liaison with one of her husband’s friends risks bringing disaster on both of them. Using carefully stylised visuals and performances, Fassbinder produces not a conventional literary adaptation but a searching study of the ways that people can unwittingly conspire in their own downfall. From the novel by Theodor Fontane. In German with English subtitles.
